verses.verse: (2 Kings 3.4; 14.7; Isa 10.32) Send lambs to the ruler of the land, from Sela, by way of the desert, to the mount of daughter Zion.
(Num 21.13, 14) Like fluttering birds, like scattered nestlings, so are the daughters of Moab at the fords of the Arnon.
(Isa 25.4) “Give counsel; grant justice; make your shade like night at the height of noon; hide the outcasts; do not betray the fugitive;

(Isa 9.4; 54.14) let the outcasts of Moab settle among you; be a refuge to them from the destroyer.” When the oppressor is no more, and destruction has ceased, and marauders have vanished from the land,

(Isa 9.7; Dan 7.14; Mic 4.7; Lk 1.33) then a throne shall be established in steadfast love in the tent of David, and on it shall sit in faithfulness a ruler who seeks justice and is swift to do what is right.
(Jer 48.29, 30; Zeph 2.8, 10) We have heard of the pride of Moab —how proud he is!— of his arrogance, his pride, and his insolence; his boasts are false.
(2 Kings 3.25; 1 Chr 16.3; Jer 48.31) Therefore let Moab wail; let everyone wail for Moab. Mourn, utterly stricken, for the raisin cakes of Kir-hareseth.

(Num 32.38; Isa 15.4; Jer 48.32) For the fields of Heshbon languish, and the vines of Sibmah, whose clusters once made drunk the lords of the nations, reached to Jazer and strayed to the desert; their shoots once spread abroad and crossed over the sea.

(Isa 15.4; Jer 40.10, 12; 48.32) Therefore I weep as Jazer weeps for the vines of Sibmah; I drench you with my tears, O Heshbon and Elealeh, for the shout over your fruit harvest and your grain harvest has ceased.

(Job 24.11; Isa 24.7, 8; Jer 48.33) Joy and gladness are taken away from the fruitful field, and in the vineyards no exultation is heard; no shouts are raised; no treader treads out wine in the presses; the vintage shout is hushed. (Cn Compare Gk: Heb I have hushed)
(Isa 15.5; 63.15; Jer 48.36) Therefore my heart moans like a harp for Moab and my very soul for Kir-heres.
(1 Kings 18.29; 2 Kings 19.12; Isa 15.2; Jer 48.35) When Moab presents himself, when he wearies himself upon the high place, when he comes to his sanctuary to pray, he will not prevail.
This was the word that the LORD spoke concerning Moab in the past.

(Isa 21.16; 25.10) But now the LORD says, “In three years, like the years of a hired worker, the glory of Moab will be brought into contempt, in spite of all its great multitude, and those who survive will be very few and feeble.”
